China. ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Engineering Research Centre of Reactive Distillation, College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350108, PR China Engineering Research Centre of Reactive Distillation, College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University Fuzhou 350108 PR China The synthesis of 1-methoxy-2-propanol (1-MP), which is expected as a safe alternative for toxic ethylene glycol ether, is highly demanded in chemical engineering. Herein, we report a series of task-specific anion-functionalized poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) to trigger an effective catalysis in the 1-MP production through a reaction of propylene oxide (PO) and methanol. The acquired PIL catalysts, which are induced by phenolate anions, allow extraordinary PO conversion of 90.8 % and outstanding 1-MP yield and selectivity of 86.5 % and 95.3 % under very mild conditions. It also feasibly applies to the catalysis of a wide range of alcohols and PO to synthesize propylene glycol ethers (PGEs), and shows robust and facilitate reusability. Through a DFT calculation and in-situ 2D-IR survey, we reason that these significant performances are enabled by hydrogen-bonding interaction from the imidazole on the backbone for PO activation, and by the unique nucleophilicity of anions for the generation of activated methanol. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Poly(ionic liquid)s Propylene glycol monomethyl ether Propylene oxide 2D-IR spectroscopy, Reaction mechanism Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene glycol methyl ether (PGME) [1,2], which is widely utilized as pollution-free solvent, detergent, intermediate in the synthesis of propylene glycol methyl ether acetate, etc, is of harvested intense interest in the chemical engineering. Conventionally, the PGME is synthesized by the reaction of propylene oxide (PO) and methanol (MeOH) because of its industrially feasible nature. As shown in Scheme 1, in the presence of catalysts with Bronsted acid sites (BF3, H2SO4), a primary alcohol (2-methoxy-1-propanol, 2-MP) is mainly formed, whereas the presence of catalysts with Lewis acid sites and basic sites affects the formation of the secondary alcohol (1-methoxy-2-propanol, 1-MP) [3,4]. Moreover, homogenous catalysts with basic sites including NaOH [3], oxides [5] and amines [1] with high catalytic activities are usually exploited in this process. However, these catalysts suffer from inevitable drawbacks of corrosion and solid waste pollution, thus limiting their further applications in this new era. To tackle these challenges, various new types of catalysts including metal oxides [6], molar sieves [7,8] metal-organic frameworks [9], ionic liquids [2,10,11] have been developed. Among them, ionic liquids [12] with low toxicity, tunable structure, high activity, and environmental friendly nature have been extensively studied in the production of 1-MP with high catalytic activity [10,13,14]. For example, Liu et al. synthesized a series of ionic liquids of [HO-EtMim][Im] featuring rich amount of hydrogen bonds and imidazole anions to produce PGME from PO at mild conditions (i.e., at room temperature), and received positive yield as high as 55 %, which over many homogenous catalysts [2]. Zhang et al. synthesized a series of ionic liquids, [Emim][OAC], by tuning their basicity and hydrogen bond networks to enhance their catalytic performance on the 1-MP production, and good yield of 61.3 % was achieved (conditions of 80 °C, PO of 60 mmol, CH3OH of 180 mmol, catalyst amount of 0.06 mmol and reaction time of 30 min were used) [10]. However, the viscosity of ionic liquids is often 2–3 orders of magnitude higher than that of common solvents which needs further energies for their mixing and separation [15,16]. In this context, developing substitutions for the ionic liquid with its advantages and additional easy-to-separate properties are highly desirable. Thus, a class of catalysts that incorporate the advantages of ionic liquids but avoid their viscosity problems are urgently to be developed. Poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs), an appearing platform with the advantage of ionic liquids and polymers, have emerged as an attractive and green protocol to achieve a transesterification under metal-free and mild conditions [17,18]. Similar to ionic liquids, the PILs could be designed by tuning its charge density, hydrogen bond and basicity to catalyze chemical reactions through a simply design of the cationic-skeleton and anions [14,19,20]. Exploiting this platform, we analyze the possibility of PILs in the 1-MP synthesis as shown in Scheme 1. A production of 1-MP by PO and MeOH requires a PO ring-open that could be allowed through connecting its O atom with the catalysts by a hydrogen bonding interaction, and through activating MeOH using a nucleophilic reaction to seize its proton. Careful analysis shows that the proton in the second position of imidazolium has a strong hydrogen bond donation nature with oxygenated species, as confirmed in the catalysis of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks for the synthesis of 1-MP [4,13,21,22]. Moreover, the nucleophilicity of PILs could be designed through an introduction of nucleophilic anions, making it show tunably strong nucleophilicity mimicking task-specific ionic liquids which provides good performance in the transesterification or etherification reaction. Therefore, fixing the imidazolium cation groups in the polymeric skeleton as hydrogen bond donor, and rationally designing functionalized-anions to enhance its nucleophilicity would be highly valuable in the design of task-specific PILs. We noted this series of PILs was rarely reported for the PO and MeOH reaction to produce 1-MP. In this work, a novel series of PILs decorated with imidazolium salts as cationic backbones and nucleophilic anions including hydroxide (OH-), phenoxide (PhO-), 2-hydroxypyridine anion (OPd-), and imidazole anion (Im-) were achieved as shown in Scheme 2. The selected monomers, with a relatively low molecular weight, have more ion-exchange sites that may give more catalytic sites for the reaction when compared to other monomers with more benzene units. They also contained both of the rigid group of benzene and the flexible group of vinyl, making the acquired PILs have good swelling property, excellent catalytic performance and heterogenous nature that could be easily separated from the reaction medium. Moreover, these monomers were relatively cheap, and could be polymerized in a very facile and mild conditions. We noted that these PILs were in solid & easy-to-separate nature at reaction temperature, and showed extensive hydrogen boding networks and feasible proton binding ability from the nucleophilic anions. The performance of our PILs thus featured extraordinary PO conversion of 90.8 % and outstanding 1-MP yield and selectivity of 86.5 % and 95.3 % under very mild conditions. It is noteworthy that this is the very first work to apply the nucleophilic anions in the trigger of reaction within the PO and MeOH, and reveal their in-depth catalytic mechanism. Outcome marks great merits of PILs in the industrial production of 1-MP, a fortunate opportunity for PILs to be further exploited. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Properties of PILs The nucleophilic anion-functionalized PILs were synthesized through the procedures as shown in Scheme 2. First, the precursor of [BVim]Cl synthesized through an addition of a biphenyl dichlorobenzyl on a vinylimidazole as confirmed by Proton Magnetic Resonance (1H NMR) and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) as shown in Fig. S1 and S2. Then, they were further polymerized to P[BVim]Cl by [BVim]Cl through a radical polymerization. We characterized the P[BVim]Cl by a FT-IR and X-ray diffraction (XRD) shown in Fig. S3 and Fig. 1(a-b). The vibration of CC and C-H in 1650 and 901 cm−1 disappeared, while other characteristic peaks of the [BVim]Cl remained in the FT-IR spectra when [BVim]Cl was polymerized to P[BVim]Cl. Moreover, the XRD pattern of [BVim]Cl was changed to a broad peak at 22.8° after its polymerization, validating again the success of the synthesis of P[BVim]Cl. We noted that this polymer was totally insoluble in organic solvents including THF, ethanol, methanol, toluene, DMF etc. due to its high cross-linking degree. To enable a nucleophilic catalysis in the reaction of MeOH and PO, we introduced the nucleophilic anions of OH-, PhO-, OPd-, and Im- to exchange with the Cl- in the P[BVim]Cl. The successful functionalization could be validated by a FT-IR and elemental analysis (EA) in Fig. 1(a), Figs. S4–6 and Table S1. For example, a group of peaks at 1244 cm−1 belonging to C-O and at 1584 and 1471 cm−1 assigning to the benzene ring skeleton vibration appeared at the FT-IR spectra of P[BVim]PhO in Fig. 1(a), while the EA results illustrated that experimental value of N/C ratio decreased with exchange of Cl- to PhO-. These trends were also seen in other anion-functionalized PILs of P[BVim]OH, P[BVim]OPd, P[BVim]Im. The ion-exchange degree of PILs might also affect the amount of catalytic sites and thus the catalytic performance [23]. Therefore, the ion-exchange degree of these PILs were tested by the acid base titration. As shown in Table S2, the ion-exchange degree of P[BVim]OH, P[BVim]PhO, P[BVim]OPd and P[BVim]Im were calculated to be 3.12, 2.82, 2.75 and 2.85 mmol g−1 respectively, confirming our PILs had high amount of ion-exchange degree that could provide rich functionalization sites for activating MeOH [24]. We also used the 13C NMR spectra to gain insight into the organic matrix, and used the XPS spectra to understand the surface state and the existence of different anions. The results were illustrated in Fig. 1(c-d) and Fig. S7. In the 13C NMR spectra in Fig. 1(c), the backbones of these PILs showed signals at 25, 39, 53 ppm attributing to the alkyl, at 138, 121 ppm ascribing the imidazole ring and at 128 ppm suggesting to benzene ring, confirming the successful polymerization of monomers[25]. When the Cl- anion in the P[BVim]Cl was exchanged to OH-, PhO-, OPd- and Im-, the peaks labeled 10, 14, 15 and 19 at 164, 163, 176 and 135 ppm respectively could be attributed to the C-O in PhO-, C-N and C-O in OPd- and C2 in Im-, respectively, confirming the Cl- anion was successfully exchanged to these anions. The full survey scan of XPS spectrum shown in Fig. S7 exhibited peaks at 284.5, 401.3, 532.3 and 197.8 eV demonstrating the C 1 s, N 1 s, O 1 s, Cl 2 p, respectively, and the signal assigning to Cl element just only appeared at the XPS spectrum of P[BVim]Cl, again illustrating the Cl anion were fully exchanged. The N 1 s XPS spectrum of P[BVim]Cl in Fig. 1(d) could be fitted with two signals with different chemical positions derived from the imidazole moiety attributing to the positively charged -N+= of imidazolium at 401.5 eV and the neutral nitrogen at 399.4 eV[26]. When the anion was exchanged to OH-, PhO-, OPd- and Im-, respectively, the peak of neutral nitrogen shifted to 399.2, 399.3, 398.6 and 398.7 eV, respectively, suggesting there were ionic interactions between imidazolium cations and these basic anions in these PILs. Moreover, there was a third peak at 399.9 eV appeared in the N 1 s XPS spectrum of P[BVim]OPd, indicating the newly appearance of -CN in the pyridine ring of OPd-. While two peaks at 401.0 and 399.9 eV attributing to -C-N- and -CN in the imidazole anion appeared in the N 1 s XPS spectrum of P[BVim]Im, again suggesting the functional anions were introduced in these PILs. These anions showed very limited influence on the stability of these PILs, as confirmed by the high thermal stability in the TGA in Fig. 1(e), ensuring the robust and stable catalysis in the reaction of PO and MeOH that requires a heating. The morphology of these PILs as investigated through SEM in Fig. 1(f) indicated a strong interaction between imidazole cationic skeleton and anions. The P[BVim]Cl showed a rough surface consisting with loads of microparticles, but turned to a dense and non-porous surface after exchange with these nucleophilic anions. This interaction was also reflected by the porosity as visualized by the N2 sorption isotherms, pore size distribution (PSD) and pore cumulation volume (PV) as shown in Fig. S9-10. Their surface areas were calculated to be less than 10 m2 g−1, but with a high cumulative pore volume as high as 0.1 cm3 g−1 and rich pore size distribution in 50–100 nm, suggesting a storage of anions in the micropores and rich porosity in mesopores acquired through the high-degree crosslinking that would facilitate the diffusion of reactants within the polymer catalysts, as reflected in the porous PILs [23,25,27]. Moreover, our PILs also showed good swelling in MeOH which could help again in the solid-liquid mass transfer as shown in Fig. S11 [28]. The volume of P[BVim]Cl and P[BVim]PhO in MeOH was compared. When the MeOH was contacted with P[BVim]Cl and P[BVim]PhO, the volume of P[BVim]Cl and P[BVim]PhO increased 10 times and 1.3 times, respectively, which might provide a good condition for the further reaction of MeOH and PO. 2.2 Synthesis of 1-MP 2.2.1 Influence of anions on the catalytic performance of 1-MP Our PILs showed significant features of rich meso-porosity, swelling property, and (attractive) nucleophilicity, marking themselves appealing platforms for the reaction of PO and MeOH to produce the 1-MP solvent. Additionally, these anions with differential nucleophilicity would allow us to explore the synergetic mechanism within our PILs in the catalytic reaction of PO and MeOH that was unreported. As a proof-of-concept, we applied these anion-functionalized PILs in the reaction of MeOH and PO for synthesis of 1-MP at mild conditions (reaction temperature of 343 K, PO usage of 10 mmol, CH3OH usage of 30 mmol, catalyst dosage of 0.375 mmol and reaction time of 3 h). We also corelated the result of 1-MP yield and the basicity of the anions in Fig. 2 (through pK a ) and Table S3 (through the pH of point of zero charge (pH pzc )) to understand the influence of the basicity of the anions on the catalysis. To study the basicity of the anions of PILs, in addition to pK a , the pH pzc could also well express alkalinity [29]. As reported, the lower pH pzc the catalyst was, the higher basicity the catalyst would have. Therefore, to further study the basicity of these PILs, we calculated the pH pzc of these PILs through a Zeta potential investigation. As shown in Fig. S12, it showed that the order of pH pzc followed an order of P[BVim]Cl> P[BVim]OH> P[BVim]PhO> P[BVim]OPd> P[BVim]Im, which was consistent with that of the pK a of their anions (as shown in Fig. 2). As shown in Fig. 2, the PIL having non-functionalized anion of Cl- with the lowest basicity among these anions showed a negative catalytic activity with 1-MP yield of 2.1 %. Significantly, the 1-MP yield increased to 60.6 % after an introduction of the nucleophilic anion of OH- with pK a of 7. A further increase in the basicity of anions to PhO- would afford a further increase in the 1-MP yield to 70.6 %, suggesting the positively tunable function of the basicity of anions in the catalytic reaction of MeOH and PO. However, when we further change the anion to OPd- or Im- with higher basicity than that of PhO-, the catalytic yield of PGME declined to 58.6 % and 62.0 %, respectively, initially suggesting the catalytic reaction is not singly dependent on the basicity, and needs further investigations (see next section for detailed discussion). For example, according to investigation reaction mechanism in the presence of ZIFs [4,21,22], activation of reagents proceeds on the Lewis acid site-basic site pair would also perform an interesting catalytic activity in this issue. As such, the optimal anion of PhO- was selected for the PIL synthesis, and the acquired PIL was exploited for the exploration of optimal reaction conditions through a response surface methodology analysis to extract the feasibility of our PILs in the 1-MP production. 2.2.2 Response surface methodology analysis for optimal conditions We apply the response surface methodology to precisely explore the feasible reaction conditions on the catalytic process [30]. The optimal temperature was first tuned, with temperature at 60 °C, 80 °C, and 100 °C investigated (a too-high reaction temperature may lead to some side reactions, and could also improve the heating cost). In addition, an appropriate increased amount of MeOH could improve the conversion rate of PO, but when the amount of MeOH is too more, the processing capacity of the equipment would be increased, and the contact probability between the PILs and PO could be reduced, thus deteriorating the catalytic performance of PILs. Therefore, appropriately different ratios of MeOH and PO (MeOH: PO = 1–5 mol: 1 mol) were used to study the effect of the ratio of alcohol to alkane on the 1-MP yield. Moreover, the number of active groups on the PILs (i.e., the amount of catalyst) could determine the catalytic rate for the catalytic synthesis of 1-MP. To find out the optimal amount of catalyst for the synthesis of 1-MP, we proposed catalyst amounts with 2 mol. % − 6 mol. % depending on PO to investigate the effect of catalyst amount on the 1-MP yield. With these parameters, the coding and coding level of the independent variables were listed in Table S4. The Box-Behnken design (BBD) experimental matrix and the results of 17 trials were summarized in Table S5. The sequence of experiments was randomly assigned for the purpose of eliminating the impacts of uncontrolled factors. After coding, the yield of 1-MP achieved within 15.7 % and 83.0 %, and the results of 5 centre point experiments showed high stability and repeatability. Regression analysis was performed on 17 sets of experimental data, and the relationship between the obtained response Y (yield) and the independent variables X 1 (reaction temperature), X 2 (catalyst amount), and X 3 (molar ratio of alcohol to alkane) could be presented by formula (1): (1) Y＝0.79＋0.19X 1 ＋6.513×10−3 X 2 ＋0.054X 3 －0.052X 1 X 2 ＋0.13X 1 X 3 ＋0.047X 2 X 3 －0.18X 1 2－0.046X 2 2－0.13X 3 2. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) was also performed on the quadratic polynomial model to verify the coefficients of the response surface model [31]. The analysis data were shown in Table S6. The data show that the P value of the regression model was extremely significant (P < 0.0001), with Lack of Fit value > 0.05. The results showed that the regression equation fitted well with the experimental results. The 3D surface and contour plots were shown in Fig. 3, and the interaction of reaction temperature, catalyst amount and molar ratio of MeOH/PO were obtained by the 3D surface and contour plots. With the summarized BBD experiment results, the optimal conditions with the reaction time of 5 h, the temperature of 90 ºC, the catalyst amount of 4 % mol (depending on PO), and the molar ratio of MeOH/PO of 3.53 were determined, and the predicted 1-MP yield of 85.8 % with PO conversion as high as 89.9 % was afforded. Therefore, three independent experiments were carried out under these optimized conditions to verify its reliability, achieving an average 1-MP yield of 86.5 %, which was in good agreement with the predicted value of the response surface model. This benchmark value marked great value for our PILs: compared to the reported heterogeneous catalyst, such as Mg-Al complex [32], ZIF [22], Fe2O3 [6], SiO2 complex [33], our PILs showed higher yield in more moderate conditions; while compared to homogeneous catalyst ionic liquid [10,14,34], our PIL could easily separate from the products with a much cheaper raw materials, but could afford similar catalytic performance under closed conditions (details see Table S7). Based on those results, anion-functionalized catalysts have outstanding potential for the 1-MP production. 2.2.3 Catalytic stability Catalyst stability, which shows great impact on the economics of the process and industrial application, is an important factor for the catalyst. The reusability of P[BVim]PhO was tested under appropriate conditions (i.e., 5 h, 363 K, catalyst amount of 4 % mol (depending on PO) and the molar ratio of MeOH/PO of 3.53) from BBD experiment result shown in Fig. 4(a). We have also carefully checked the heterogeneous process in the presence of these samples. These samples maintained obvious heterogeneous nature during the reaction, and thus could be easily separated and recycling used by a quick centrifugation and vacuum drying. The conversion of PO and the yield of 1-MP have no obvious change, with the conversion as high as 90.8 % and yield as high as 86.9 % after at least 5-cycle reuses, while the molecular structure of the P[BVim]PhO measured by FT-IR shown in Fig. 4(b) before and after use were nearly identical, validating the robust stability of P[BVim]PhO (slight difference in the FTIR spectra might be resulted from the organic impurities or reaction products). 2.2.4 Generality of catalyst Extensive alcohols such as ethanol, propanol, butanol for the propylene glycol ethers (PGEs) synthesis was investigated for the survey of the catalytic generality of our PILs shown in Fig. 5 (reaction condition: 5 h, 363 K, catalyst amount of 4 % mol (depending on PO) and the molar ratio of MeOH/PO of 3.53). The results illustrate that yields of products decreased with the increase of alcohol chain length, but still show ultrahigh performance that outperformed most of the previously reported materials (see Table S8). Moreover, the influence manner of anions on the catalysis of PILs was well applied to the catalytic reaction of the PO and ethanol, propanol, butanol (shown in Fig. S13-16), in which the P[BVim]PhO consistently showed the best catalytic performance, suggesting the generality of the reaction mechanism enabled by our anion-induced PILs. 2.3 The possible mechanism on anion-induced PILs for the PGME catalysis To understand the catalytic mechanism, the Gibbs free energy charge (∆G; ∆G was calculated by ΔG=∑v(B)× ∆G(B)) of these PILs in the catalytic reaction of PO and MeOH were calculated respectively using the density functional theory (DFT) calculation in a Gaussian 16 [35], and the feasible B3LYP method and 6–31 G* *(d, p) basis set were used [36]. As shown in Table S9, all of the PILs with MeOH had very negative ∆G, initially suggesting the catalytic reaction mechanism was induced from PILs and MeOH. This result was also reflected by the FT-IR spectrum of PILs adsorbed with MeOH (P[BVim]X-MeOH) shown in Fig. S17. The bending vibration of MeOH at a peak position of 1018 cm−1 (assigned to O-H) had no significant displacement in the FT-IR spectrum of P[BVim]Cl-MeOH sample when compared to that of the pure MeOH, while it moved to around 1025 cm−1 in the FT-IR spectra of anion-functionalized PIL-MeOH samples, indicating a strong interaction within the anion-functionalized PILs and MeOH that could activate the MeOH for the further reaction with PO. A careful investigation on the |∆G| in Table S9 exhibited a slight incoherence between the catalytic performance and |∆G| in the anion-functionalized PILs, indicating the activation of MeOH by the anions was not the single mechanism for the promising catalysis. To obtain more insight into the catalytic mechanism of anion-functionalization in PILs, the Electrostatic Potentials (ESP) and the O Mulliken atomic charge density of oxygen atoms on the MeOH under the interaction of anions in the PILs-MeOH composite were calculated by DFT as shown in Fig. 6(a-b) to reflect the impact of nucleophilicity of the anions on the reaction. In the ESPs in Figs. 6(a) and S19, the Cl, O or N functionalized sites on the anions, which had different electronegativity and different degrees of red color of ESP, could interact with protons on the MeOH to varying degrees. When these PILs was mixed with MeOH, the unfunctionalized PIL with Cl- having the lowest catalytic performance showed the most positive potential value in O-CH3 with P[BVim]PhO-MeOH (i.e., with the color of ESP closest to yellow) and the lowest Mulliken atomic charge density as summarized in Table S9, while the PIL functionalized with phenolate anions having the highest catalytic performance had the most negative potential value in O-CH3 with P[BVim]PhO-MeOH (i.e., with the color of ESP closest to red) and the highest Mulliken atomic charge density. We therefore corelated the Mulliken atomic charge density values and 1-MP yield in Fig. 6(b), and it was interestingly found that the very high correlatability between the O Mulliken atomic charge density and the 1-MP yield, suggesting the 1-MP yield was highly depended on the nucleophilicity, and confirming the success of our nucleophilic anion-induced PILs in the 1-MP production. However, when these PILs were mixed and reacted with the PO, the ESPs in Fig. S20 showed no obvious change. Therefore, the catalytic reaction mechanism was induced from PILs and MeOH first. Inspired by the calculation results, we further monitored the detailed reaction of MeOH and PO through an in-situ IR and 2D-IR spectroscopy [37–39] shown in Fig. 6(c-e) to reveal the catalytic process of this series of PILs, while the optimal P[BVim]PhO was used as an example. The intensities of the vibration absorption of O-H in 1027 cm−1 and C-O vibration absorption of 1-MP in 1104 cm−1 produced and increased with time, indicating the gradual yield of 1-MP. In addition, the vibration absorption of phenolate anion at 1584 cm−1 gradually shifted to 1600 cm−1, while the absorption intensity of C-H in the imidazole on the polymer networks at 825 cm−1 decreased with the reaction conducting on, initially suggesting the synergetic assistance of phenolate anion and C-H in imidazole to the PO for the reaction with MeOH. The 2D correction-form IR spectra of PILs associated with the MeOH and PO further confirmed the group interaction proposed above (Fig. 6(d-e)). It was interesting that the absorption between 800 and 1600 cm−1 consists with several peaks when compared with synchronous and asynchronous correction of P[BVim]PhO with MeOH and PO complex, and there were cross correlation peaks marked with the elliptical line appeared at (1027 cm−1, 1584 cm−1), where 1584 cm−1 was assigned to phenolate anion and 1027 cm−1 was belonged to O-H in MeOH. In this issue, the Ψ (1027 cm−1, 1584 cm−1) in Fig. 6(d) is opposite to signs of Φ (1027 cm−1, 1584 cm−1) in Fig. 6(e), which indicate the strong relationship between phenolate anions at 1580 cm−1 and MeOH at 1027 cm−1, thus validating the activation of phenolate anions on the MeOH. We also studied the interaction of imidazole and PO with the analysis of the correlation among the peaks at 825, 1027 and 1268 cm−1 (in which 825 cm−1 belonged to the C-H in imidazole, and 1268 cm−1 could be assigned to C-O in PO). It could be seen that the Ψ (825 cm−1, 1268 cm−1) showed the opposite signs to Φ (825 cm−1, 1268 cm−1), while the Ψ (1104 cm−1, 1027 cm−1) had the opposite signs to Φ (1104 cm−1, 1027 cm−1), illustrating that it was C-H in the imidazole that would induce the ring-open of PO during the reaction [40]. We reasoned that this ring-open was caused by the strong hydrogen bond provided from the imidazole, which may allow a further reaction with the MeOH as activated by the nucleophilic anions to produce 1-MP [40]. The promising catalytic mechanism of this class of anion-functionalized PILs was summarized in Fig. 7. At the initial of reaction, the nucleophilic anion (i.e., phenolate anions) in PILs would interact with MeOH to activate it from MeOH to MeO-H-X (X represented a functional group for the MeOH activation) through its nucleophilicity, while the ring of PO would be opened (or activated) by C-H in imidazole (thus forming carbine) by a hydrogen bonding interaction. Next, the activated MeO-H-X would attack the activated PO at a less steric-hindered carbon atom through a typical SN2 process, and generate an unstable charge-separated intermediate. This intermediate would finally modify its charge distribution via a proton transfer with the hydrogen-bond linked species nearby, thus facially releasing a product molecule of 1-MP. Therefore, the nucleophilic anion functionalization coupling with the imidazole-rich networks were the keys to allow the promising catalytic production of 1-MP. 3 Conclusions In conclusion, we reported a series of anion-functionalized PILs to provide an effective catalysis in the production of 1-MP, through a reaction of PO and methanol. With the highly nucleophilic anion functionalization and the imidazole-rich networks, P[BVim]PhO showed an efficient 86.5 % of 1-MP yield & conversion of PO as high as 90.8 % under very mild reaction conditions, and robust reusability & promising catalytic generality that also applied to the many other alcohol including ethanol, propanol, and butanol. We, based on the DFT calculation and the precious in-situ IR and 2D-IR spectroscopy, revealed the catalytic mechanism of our PILs, and validated the task-specific activation on MeOH and PO through our introduced nucleophilic anions and imidazole groups on the polymer networks. Outcomes confirm the great merit of nucleophilic anion-functionalized PILs as potential catalysts for industrial 1-MP production, and provide a rational guidance towards the design and synthesis of a wide range of efficient catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of 1-methoxy-2-propanol (1-MP), which is expected as a safe alternative for toxic ethylene glycol ether, is highly demanded in chemical engineering. Herein, we report a series of task-specific anion-functionalized poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) to trigger an effective catalysis in the 1-MP production through a reaction of propylene oxide (PO) and methanol. The acquired PIL catalysts, which are induced by phenolate anions, allow extraordinary PO conversion of 90.8 % and outstanding 1-MP yield and selectivity of 86.5 % and 95.3 % under very mild conditions. It also feasibly applies to the catalysis of a wide range of alcohols and PO to synthesize propylene glycol ethers (PGEs), and shows robust and facilitate reusability. Through a DFT calculation and in-situ 2D-IR survey, we reason that these significant performances are enabled by hydrogen-bonding interaction from the imidazole on the backbone for PO activation, and by the unique nucleophilicity of anions for the generation of activated methanol.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the mechanism for the synthesis of 1-methoxy-2-propanol over basic poly(ionic liquid) catalysts
